section.title: Cartesian Products and Power Sets

definition.title: Cartesian Product
definition.statement: Let A and B be sets. The Cartesian product of A and B, denoted by A\times B, is defined as follows: A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a \in A \quad\textrm{ and }\quad b \in B\}, that is, A\times B is the set of all possible ordered pairs whose first component comes from A and whose second component comes from B.

notation.description: The cartesian product of A with B.

example.title: Some Cartesian Products
example.p: Notation in mathematics is often developed for good reason. In this case, a few examples will make clear why the symbol $\times $ is used for Cartesian products.

li.p: Let A = \{1, 2, 3\} and B = \{4, 5\}. Then A \times B = \{(1, 4), (1, 5), (2, 4), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5)\}. Note that |A \times B| = 6 = \lvert A \rvert \times \lvert B \rvert .

section.p: These two examples illustrate the general rule: If A and B are finite sets, then | A \times B | = \lvert A \rvert \times \lvert B \rvert .
We can define the Cartesian product of three (or more) sets similarly. For example, A \times B \times C = \{(a, b, c):a \in A, b \in B, c \in C\}.

It is common to use exponents if the sets in a Cartesian product are the same: A^2= A \times A A^3=A \times A \times A and in general, A^n = \underset{n \textrm{ factors}}{\underline{A \times A \times \ldots \times A}}.

definition.title: Power Set
definition.statement: If A is any set, the power set of A is the set of all subsets of A, denoted \mathcal{P}(A).

notation.description: The power set of A, the set of all subsets of A.

section.p: The two extreme cases, the empty set and all of A, are both included in \mathcal{P}(A).

example.title: Some Power Sets
example.p: We will leave it to you to guess at a general formula for the number of elements in the power set of a finite set. In Chapter 2, we will discuss counting rules that will help us derive this formula.
